qas.question: What does Archibald Sayce think early Sumerian pictograms suggest about the availability of stone?
How did the Sumerians fashion the stone they cut?
What was the ordinary building material of Sumerians?
What kind of appearance did Sumerian houses have?
What were the foundation stones of Sumerian houses consecrated by?

answers.text: objects that were deposited under them

qas.question: What suggested that stone was common?
Who claims stone was common in Sumeria since it was used for seals?
Where were towers built from stone?

context: According to <b6_0>Archibald Sayce,<b6_0/> <b5_0>the primitive pictograms<b5_0/> of the early Sumerian (i.e. Uruk) era suggest that "Stone <a0_0>was scarce<a0_0/>, but was already cut <a1_0>into blocks and seals<a1_0/>. <a2_0>Brick<a2_0/> was the ordinary building material, and with it <b7_0>cities, forts, temples<b7_0/> and houses were constructed. The city was provided with towers and stood on an artificial platform; the house also had a <a3_0>tower-like<a3_0/> appearance. It was provided with a door which turned on a hinge, and could be opened with a sort of key; the city gate was on a larger scale, and seems to have been double. The foundation stones — or rather bricks — of a house were consecrated by certain <a4_0>objects that were deposited under them<a4_0/>."
